image.altText: A close up on a woman looking seriously at the camera. She is older, and looks sad. The background is black.

props.synopsis: A crisis inside one of northern Australia's most important legal entities has led to a severe shortage of lawyers in Alice Springs, leaving some of Australia's most vulnerable residents to represent themselves in court.

title.children: 'National disgrace': Verna's son has been locked up for two months and hasn't been able to access a lawyer

image.altText: a blonde woman in a floral dress holding a photo of her father

props.synopsis: It's been 82 years since Japanese fighters launched a deadly air raid on the Northern Territory in World War II. Yvonne's Odegaard's father was among the survivors.

title.children: Decades after the bombing of Darwin, family secrets continue to be unearthed

image.altText: The front of a Coles supermarket. Underneath a large sign are displays of fruit and vegetables.

props.synopsis: Leaked emails reveal for the first time the tactics Coles employs when a supplier seeks a price increase and how it has taken advantage of inflation to boost profits.

title.children: Coles said no to raising the price of a product… until its supplier made a $25k payment

image.altText: Supporters hold signs and flags at a pro-Palestine rally outside Parliament House in Canberra.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese has been trying to play the role of unifier when it comes to the conflict in the Middle East and the schisms it's causing in Australia. But as community tensions rise, so do frustrations about where this all ends, writes Patricia Karvelas.

title.children: Something disturbing is going on in Australian communities — and it's sparking many conversations in Canberra

image.altText: Katrina Gorry

props.synopsis: After the Matildas’ World Cup glory, star midfielder Katrina Gorry introduces us to the tiny secret weapon who rekindled her love for the game.

title.children: At the top of her game but battling to get out of bed, Katrina Gorry reveals how she overcame her 'dark place'

image.altText: Emma Stone, as main character Bella Baxter, holds a hardcover book and looks worrying to the side.

props.synopsis: Oppenheimer and Poor Things take out the top awards at the BAFTAs, with all Australian nominees going home empty-handed.

title.children: Oppenheimer, Poor Things dominate BAFTAs as Barbie goes home empty handed — as it happened

image.altText: A woman standing in front of a book shelf.

props.synopsis: The general insurance industry's delaying and denying of claims and low-balling of cash settlement offers in the aftermath of the 2022 floods weren't isolated — the tactics are rife across the sector, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: General insurers use a variety of dirty tricks to knock back claims. A slew of harrowing stories show it's getting worse

image.altText: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese looking serious in headshot outside in a park

props.synopsis: The federal government and opposition trade barbs as a group of nearly 40 foreign nationals who arrived by boat to a remote part of WA on Friday is transferred to an offshore detention centre in Nauru.

title.children: PM accuses opposition of being 'cheer squad' for people smugglers as row over boat arrivals continues

image.altText: A man sits in a chair with his back to the camera, fishing rod in hand in muddy waters. There is a 100kph speed sign behind.

props.synopsis: While record rain causes havoc in south-east Queensland, it revitalises a part of far west Queensland that rarely sees so much water.

title.children: Floodwaters transform this outback desert into a green oasis, but it's not all good news

image.altText: Aerial view of cave

props.synopsis: A new study, based in a cave in rural SA, proves Australia's ice ages were friendlier to our First Nations people than first thought.

title.children: This 'underground library' shows what Australia's climate was like 350,000 years ago

image.altText: A full moon rises over Monument Valley Navajo Tribal Park

props.synopsis: Space is often described as the Wild West, but this is changing with commercial operators now charging people to send human ashes of loved ones to the Moon. But there are ethical implications around whether this should be allowed.

title.children: People are sending their human remains to the Moon, and not everyone's happy about it

image.altText: Fence with a danger asbestos sign at the Rozelle Parklands as the clean up continues

props.synopsis: The NSW Environment Protection Agency said that 41 sites have been identified as having bonded asbestos, with 683 tests returning negative results since last month.

title.children: Another school, supermarket among new sites identified as Sydney asbestos debacle grows

image.altText: SoSo portraits

props.synopsis: Running clubs are rapidly growing in popularity across Australia, and organisers say it's thanks to social media providing support and accountability.

title.children: Thousands of Aussies have joined community running clubs recently with social media fuelling the trend

image.altText: Alexei Navalny

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says the death of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny in an Arctic penal colony is an "appalling atrocity" and Vladimir Putin is to blame.

title.children: Albanese blames Putin for Alexei Navalny's death

image.altText: A group of people all loaded up into the back of a small truck with no back door.

props.synopsis: Fighting, fuel shortages and Israeli raids have put the Nasser Hospital in the southern city of Khan Younis out of service, health officials say.

title.children: Patients forced to evacuate Gaza's second-largest hospital, local and United Nations health officials say

image.altText: A smoker lights up a cigarette

props.synopsis: Smokers are stereotypically thought to be those who are uneducated, unemployed and generally suffering from mental illness. But while smoking rates are higher among these groups, most daily smokers are actually employed, educated and in good mental health.

title.children: Typical smokers are not the stereotypes we've been led to believe, study finds

image.altText: A man sitting in a chair wearing a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Candidates are being finalised for Tasmania's upcoming state election. For many, it's not their first rodeo.

title.children: Ten more seats are up for grabs. But will Tasmania get fresh faces or party stalwarts?

image.altText: China's Qinling base

props.synopsis: When China opened its fifth research station in Antarctica this month, analysts sounded alarm bells about potential security threats on Australia's southern doorstep.

title.children: Security concerns grow as China opens its fifth base in Antarctica

image.altText: Ilia Topuria hits Alexander Volkanovski withi his right hand during UFC 298.

props.synopsis: Unbeaten Ilia Topuria stops Alexander Volkanovski in the second round to claim the featherweight title at UFC 298, ending the Australian champion's four-year reign.

title.children: Aussie Volkanovski relinquishes UFC featherweight title after KO loss

image.altText: A man holds two ventriloquist dummies overlaid on a composite of old newspaper articles

props.synopsis: In 1937, one of the most popular names in American radio stood just 90 centimetres tall and was made of wood and plastic — meet Charlie McCarthy and his puppeteer, Edgar Bergen.

title.children: Famous ventriloquist left his daughter nothing when he died — he bequeathed his puppet a fortune

image.altText: A woman hugging a man from behind

props.synopsis: From Australia to the US, these South Asian women share what being in an interracial relationship has cost them.

title.children: 'Out of bounds': Women explain the complications of interracial relationships

image.altText: A composite image of two men with neutral expressions

props.synopsis: Of all Vladimir Putin's critics, Alexei Navalny was probably the most fearless. It's one of the reasons he was so dangerous for the Russian president.

title.children: Navalny had a choice to stay a free man. This is why he decided to return to Russia

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: I know exactly your type — you love a weekend quiz and are convinced you'd outperform contestants on my show. Well, prove it.

title.children: Think you're a trivia guru? Let's see about that

image.altText: The buffet car of the Albany train, 1970.

props.synopsis: The WA government once offered train holidays around the state with sleeping cars, on-board dining, and a chance to see the sights on 'reso tours'.

title.children: In the golden age of railway, the WA government ran affordable holidays to show off the state's attractions

image.altText: Year of the Dragon

props.synopsis: For some Chinese communities observing Lunar New Year, adhering to specific rituals — from early preparations, to visiting etiquette and food choices — help set the tone for the rest of the year. We asked you to share some of the practices so we can unpack their symbolism and significance.

title.children: How did cultural practices over Lunar New Year come about and what do they symbolise?

image.altText: a family of five hugging on the beach

props.synopsis: A new study argues feminist language is being co-opted to sell health interventions that aren't backed up by evidence — like the anti-Müllerian hormone "egg timer" test.

title.children: Carla was told menopause was 'around the corner' and she didn't need birth control — all based on a hormone test

image.altText: Angela Webster smiles at the camera in front of a box of fruit and veggies which she gets as part of a Sydney food co-op

props.synopsis: As the weekly grocery shop becomes increasingly more expensive for households, a dozen families are keeping a decades-old tradition alive in Sydney's inner west to get their fresh produce for the week.

title.children: Sydney families pool their money to buy groceries in bulk — it's saving them hundreds of dollars

image.altText: Ambika, left, sits in a grassy park with Leo laying down next to her, right. Both grin.

props.synopsis: Here's what's new to streaming and actually good in February, from the two surprisingly great remakes One Day and Mr and Mrs Smith, to the workplace satire that will make you lol.

title.children: Prepare to get your heart broken by David Nicholls's One Day all over again
